data.text: Lagarde: We will announce our intentions for our bond-buying programme in December. Even after the end of the emergency, it is important to keep financing conditions favourable to support the recovery. https://t.co/tuFB4BIIp0
Lagarde: We still expect inflation to moderate next year. It will take longer to decline than originally expected, but we continue to foresee inflation below our new 2% target in the medium term.

Lagarde: The inflation rate increased by more than we anticipated in September, standing at 4.1% in October.

This upswing has been driven by:
▪️ energy prices
▪️ recovery in demand linked to the reopening
▪️ reversal of the German VAT cut https://t.co/lwEl2Hiz5t

Lagarde: Economic activity continued to recover strongly in the third quarter. Quarterly gross domestic product (GDP) growth stood at 2.2% and is still expected to exceed its pre-pandemic level around the end of the year. https://t.co/dAwT7IyiqE
@Lagarde President @Lagarde's introductory statement in charts https://t.co/iFU4Yx9TYo
Introductory statement by President Christine @Lagarde at the hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/RT39C8B5IU

Live now: President @Lagarde speaks before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the @Europarl_EN and answers questions from its members. Follow here https://t.co/ZmDFJOXieH @EP_Economics https://t.co/dZKKVRu8gS

Tune in at 11:00 CET to watch President Christine @Lagarde speak before the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN and answer questions from its members. Follow the webcast here https://t.co/ZmDFJOXieH @EP_Economics https://t.co/eoKhjU1lxA
https://t.co/nyqhci4poY https://t.co/7j2ffGfxZY

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/OPCn5sXHC4 
3/3

The paper looks at different factors that can affect productivity, including structural trends like globalisation and climate change, as well as the coronavirus pandemic. It also looks at how monetary policy and productivity influence each other 
2/3

(THREAD) Understanding what drives productivity, innovation and technological progress and how these interact with monetary policy was an important part of our strategy review. We recently published the research that fed into our discussions https://t.co/OPCn5sXHC4 
1/3 https://t.co/5uKm2lVicb
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/PFzEBWbzxO
Speech Philip R. Lane: The future of the EU fiscal governance framework: a macroeconomic perspective https://t.co/pm0Kcuo6ck

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/SSFDhAjjww 
3/3

The paper covers many topics, including:
1⃣how monetary policy can help employment without compromising on price stability by considering the ECB’s medium-term policy horizon
2⃣how employment income and wealth inequality can affect the effectiveness of monetary policy
2/3

(THREAD) Our monetary policy can contribute to the EU’s full employment goal, without overriding our price stability mandate. This was one of the topics in our recent strategy review and we recently published the research that fed into our discussions https://t.co/SSFDhA1IEY
1/3 https://t.co/ZoAUbyRuUm

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area https://t.co/4Zd3hdnetn
3/3

Adopting new technologies affects different aspects of the economy, especially:
1⃣ How we measure prices
2⃣ Productivity and potential output
3⃣ Labour markets
4⃣ Inflation
2/3

(THREAD) Digitalisation is transforming our economies, and it affects our efforts to keep prices stable. That’s why it was one of the focuses of our recent strategy review. We have recently published the research that provided input to our discussion https://t.co/4Zd3hdnetn
1/3 https://t.co/PHdtrzCIvY

Congratulations to our colleague Doris Schneeberger, who will take the helm of our banknotes department from 1 February 2022.
 
We look forward to working with Doris in her new role!
 
Press release https://t.co/VGw4gOJVvC https://t.co/2hZZLlox0h

The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more https://t.co/xatfGLi1np https://t.co/48iSql3xJC
Euro area securities issues statistics (Sept 2021) https://t.co/Pm6xIalBgT
Results of a special survey of professional forecasters on the ECB’s new monetary policy strategy https://t.co/iL6HcV7qOV

Is there momentum towards greater banking integration? Will we have a European deposit guarantee scheme?
Tune in from 12:00 CET to watch our panellists discuss this and more at the #ECBForum on Banking Supervision https://t.co/iNqZrVbYVZ https://t.co/hMekX3wjvd

The pandemic sped up firms’ digitalisation and triggered a productivity-raising redistribution of resources, but could weaken investment and increase skill mismatches. The outlook is still uncertain 2/2

(THREAD) Labour productivity in the euro area grew faster during the pandemic than before it, driven by a large fall in hours worked. In the second quarter of 2021 productivity was 2% higher than in the pre-pandemic period https://t.co/QXPuy2KYHN #EconomicBulletin 1/2 https://t.co/z0NXoQ79wk

Productivity growth is a key determinant of potential output growth and the natural rate of interest. In the euro area it has been subdued for years owing to a variety of interacting factors https://t.co/xH2CffNSMI #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/vdeNLNXkOA

Have banks and supervisors adapted to the new reality of climate change? Is addressing climate risks more of a benefit or a cost to banks?
Tune in from 10:30 CET to watch our panellists discuss this and more at the #ECBForum on Banking Supervision https://t.co/iNqZrVbYVZ https://t.co/QxVZnZE3aB

The recession caused by the pandemic led to a decline in global potential output, but the driving factors are likely to be temporary. Future developments depend on post-pandemic economic adjustments and the phasing-out of policy support https://t.co/FQscD8SwvH #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/nsuAR1fVkF

Coming up from 10:00 CET: Day 2 of the #ECBForum on Banking Supervision.

➡️ speech by Commissioner Mairead @McGuinnessEU
➡️ panel discussion on climate change
➡️ panel discussion on banking sector integration

Follow live here https://t.co/iNqZrVbYVZ https://t.co/xP10Gif2Up

Monetary policy reduces labour income inequality but may raise wealth inequality, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. The ECB should choose and calibrate its instruments to ensure price stability, while minimising potential distributional effects https://t.co/6Hu1N0cVNb https://t.co/MrcCaLDAfM

Is today’s credit risk management adequate to deal with tomorrow’s challenges? Are investors confident that the worst is behind us?
Tune in from 15:00 CET today to watch our panellists discuss this and more at the #ECBForum on Banking Supervision https://t.co/iNqZrVbYVZ https://t.co/7oep997z29
Live from 15:00 CET ⬇️ https://t.co/k91zwv4oKS

Lagarde: The full impact of the pandemic on banks will become visible only gradually. Supervisors need to keep a close eye on the build-up of risks. For banks to thrive they need to prepare for future challenges such as digitalisation and climate change
3/3

Lagarde: Having a single supervisor meant that we could take bold collective action to reduce banks’ natural incentives to retrench and cut lending to the economy during a recession. And, crucially, this could happen in all countries simultaneously and without delay
2/3

(THREAD) European banking supervision ensured that during the pandemic, unlike in past crises, banks acted as shock absorbers rather than amplifiers, says President @Lagarde in her welcome address at the #ECBForum on Banking Supervision https://t.co/cZx8kqaWFI
1/3 https://t.co/TWN7G3SqqB

Coming up from 14:00 CET: Day 1 of the #ECBForum on Banking Supervision.

 ➡️ President Christine @Lagarde opens the Forum
 ➡️ Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in conversation with Maria Tadeo @mariatd
➡️ panel discussion on credit risk

Follow live https://t.co/iNqZrVbYVZ https://t.co/xP10Gif2Up
Economic Bulletin box: The recovery of housing demand through the lens of the ECB Consumer Expectations Survey https://t.co/3BsMOTUeG7

The outlook for the euro area housing market remains uncertain. It is still highly dependent on how the pandemic develops, supply bottlenecks, the withdrawal of policy support, how people use their savings and changes in housing preferences 3/3
The housing market remained resilient in the face of the second and third waves of the pandemic owing to the strong fiscal, monetary and macroprudential policy response 2/3

(THREAD) During the first wave of the pandemic, restrictions on mobility strongly affected euro area housing investment. In contrast to previous crises, the economic shock did not slow the upward trend in house prices and loans https://t.co/jSFld6jJuV #EconomicBulletin 1/3 https://t.co/hif8Pf3TEf

Watch live now: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta joins a panel discussing the policy implications of digital currencies at the @SuomenPankki @BOFITresearch conference https://t.co/IqsYPFfHZi https://t.co/EYkxdshsu0

Coming up from 15:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane will join @federalreserve Vice Chair @RichardClarida and @BrookingsInst distinguished fellow @benbernanke on the panel discussing the new Fed and ECB monetary policy frameworks https://t.co/Lzx1rSPNsJ https://t.co/Uc5g8ZcWMA

Lane: In addition to rate forward guidance, the calibration of asset purchases plays a major role in ensuring that the monetary stance is sufficiently accommodative to deliver 2% inflation in the medium term https://t.co/E8MRwlCrYR
4/4

Lane: In the near term, supply bottlenecks and rising energy prices are the main risks to the recovery and the outlook for inflation. However, economic activity could outperform our expectations if consumers become more confident and save less than expected
3/4

Lane: Our analysis shows three temporary factors pushing up inflation now are projected to fade over the next year: 
1) unusually low prices during 2020 and temporary tax cuts
2) an unexpectedly strong recovery that is causing supply bottlenecks
3) a surge in energy prices
2/4

(THREAD) Monetary policy affects inflation with a considerable time lag. Abrupt tightening of policy would not lower inflation now but slow the economy and cost jobs, leading to inflation below our 2% target later, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane
1/4 https://t.co/AQ4owCqwK2
Follow live today at 14:10 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane will open our Money Market Conference https://t.co/MyhHdgnnwt https://t.co/Ecx8TkKyQN

Contact-intensive services, like travel and restaurants, recovered strongly in 2021 and have been the main drivers of growth as economies reopen. Changes in consumer preferences and working arrangements may affect these sectors in future https://t.co/7tzdUReGAO #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/m07oT7Wan6

The euro area current account surplus grew to €337 billion (2.9% of GDP) in the year to the second quarter of 2021. Germany, Italy and the Netherlands recorded the largest surpluses. Explore our external statistics dashboard to find out more https://t.co/Nf5jbRqzsO https://t.co/X3dRJneYIS
POLL: Join the conversation at this week’s #ECBForum on tomorrow’s banking in a changing world. What do you think is the biggest challenge facing Europe’s banking sector?

Lane on monetary policy: Our decisions will be based on what is needed to make sure that inflation stabilises at 2% over the medium term. We have several policy tools at our disposal, including asset purchases and interest rates
3/3

(THREAD) Inflation is unexpectedly high at the moment, but we believe it will fall next year, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @el_pais. In our monetary policy, we have to be patient and not overreact to a temporary increase in inflation https://t.co/DsNKfDDSwJ
1/3 https://t.co/js7mr7fPE0
Aggregate results of the ECB Survey of Monetary Analysts (October, 2021) https://t.co/CgzjWK3XHR

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/KGrJBcvBL3 
3/3

The paper covers many topics, including:
1⃣how physical and transition risks affect the economy and prices
2⃣how to reflect these risks in our macroeconomic modelling, including our projections
3⃣what central banks can do within their mandates to tackle climate change
2/3

(THREAD) Climate change is a clear and present danger for the economy. As part of our strategy review, we set out an ambitious roadmap for taking climate change into account in our work. We recently published the research that fed into our discussions https://t.co/KGrJBcvBL3 
1/3 https://t.co/Qcu7YYzTFB

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/t1U1T7mqR5
3/3

The paper covers many topics, including:
1⃣ the possibility of an optimal inflation level
2⃣ the pros and cons of defining the inflation objective in terms of a focal point or a range
3⃣ alternative policy approaches for achieving price stability 
2/3

(THREAD) Our new price stability objective is 2%. This was the main outcome of our recent strategy review. The research that fed into our review looks at our past experiences with our price stability framework, and the current and future challenges https://t.co/t1U1T7mqR5
1/3 https://t.co/Dm4SvA3Ib6

Panetta: We are working to make the digital euro an attractive means of payment for everyone. The digital euro would offer a cost-free and convenient way to pay digitally anywhere in the euro area, and new services could be developed with “digital euro inside”. 4/4

Panetta: Now that people are shifting towards digital payments and demand for cash as a means of exchange may weaken, we need to ensure the use of central bank money also in digital form. A digital euro would provide a monetary anchor for digital innovation.
3/4

Panetta: People’s confidence in private money depends on its convertibility with central bank money, the safest form of money in the economy. The smooth functioning of payment systems ultimately depends on everyone being able to widely access and use sovereign money.
2/4

Central bank money provides the reference value for all other forms of money, underpinning confidence in the currency, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. A digital euro would provide the monetary anchor for the digital era. Read the speech https://t.co/dIkPNk0TqX
1/4 https://t.co/u8NGuUMOfP
Follow live today at 12:00 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta speaks about the digital euro at the @rielcano https://t.co/zeMqrYxDpp https://t.co/R9B5L33CmK

Live from 14:10, Day 2 of the virtual ECB-@CEPR_org Women in Economics Conference. On today’s agenda:
1⃣Monetary policy transmission and monetary policy redistribution
2⃣Central banking session
Watch the final day here https://t.co/INIv71XPkC https://t.co/QOpOt2OyG0

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area 
https://t.co/7yLdvbYymR
4/4

By and large, our 2% headline inflation buffer was enough to prevent low or negative inflation in euro area countries from 1999 to 2019. There were some exceptions after the financial crisis, when inflation was a lot lower than in the first decade of the euro
3/4

There were two main reasons for having an inflation buffer in the euro area:
1⃣ to help grease the wheels of the economy in the face of price and wage rigidities 
2⃣ to limit different price developments across countries – particularly important in a monetary union
2/4

(THREAD) Our monetary policy and price stability objective are oriented towards the euro area as a whole, but they must consider national differences across countries. 
Why is having an inflation buffer particularly important for the euro area?⬇️ https://t.co/7yLdvbYymR 
1/4 https://t.co/S6sEaSlCMO

Live from 13:55, Day 1 of the virtual ECB-@CEPR_org Women in Economics Conference. On today’s agenda:
1⃣Opening remarks by President @Lagarde
2⃣Microeconomics session
3⃣International finance session
4⃣Policy panel “Rebuilding after COVID”

Watch here https://t.co/oqthGwyEI4 https://t.co/VQmcnfI5iD

The short-term costs of the green transition are heavily outweighed by the benefits in the long run, as our economy-wide climate stress test showed. Clear milestones on the path to zero carbon could help guide our way https://t.co/gBfy7kdJuL
4/4

Central banks have a part to play too. The impact of natural catastrophes and the green transition on inflation directly affects price stability. We've just pledged to contribute to meeting the Paris Agreement’s goals in five areas within our mandate https://t.co/D3goISupq0 
3/4

Transition paths need:
✅ carbon pricing that fully reflects carbon’s societal and environmental impact, which is not yet the case
✅ financial institutions to outline their plans to adapt to a carbon-free world, given their important role in the transition 
2/4

(THREAD) The @COP26 summit is a vital opportunity to set out a clear path towards a zero-carbon world, President @Lagarde writes in #TheECBBlog. While the road to get there may seem daunting, clear signposts will break it up into more manageable stages https://t.co/gBfy7kdJuL
1/4 https://t.co/eSNmZ7aUbD

Last week we hosted an awareness event on the economy of cybercrime. Experts from @EC3Europol and @UniofOxford shed light on how cybercriminals work and on common threats like the selling of people’s card data. Watch the recording here https://t.co/7CLodR7k44 https://t.co/n15cL5ccUP

Mandatory legal requirements for banks to have Paris-compatible transition plans would be welcome, says @FrankElderson in his @BloombergTV interview. This way, supervisors can easily check banks’ alignment with the Paris Agreement
2/3

(THREAD) We need banks to incorporate climate risks into their DNA. For a bank, this is not a fringe activity, this is core. This is what our supervisory expectations are about, Executive Board member @FrankElderson tells @flacqua in a @BloombergTV interview at @COP26
1/3

We pledge to contribute towards the Paris Agreement goals within our mandate. On the occasion of @COP26, we have set out five areas of decisive action to address climate change. We are committed to achieving them.

Read the full ECB pledge here https://t.co/XubTBnk6BS

#COP26 https://t.co/TWalXpbcwf

Lagarde: An undue tightening of financing conditions is not desirable at a time when purchasing power is already being squeezed by higher energy and fuel bills, and it would represent an unwarranted headwind for the recovery.

Read the full speech https://t.co/oMU4yUd3Uw

3/3

Lagarde: We continue to use our pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) to safeguard favourable financing conditions and ensure that borrowing costs for all sectors of the economy do not unduly tighten.

2/3

(THREAD) Despite the current inflation surge, the outlook for inflation over the medium term remains subdued, says President Christine @Lagarde.

Thus, the three conditions that need to be satisfied before rates start to rise are very unlikely to be met next year.

1/3 https://t.co/d6QpjDQRHW
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (September 2021) https://t.co/UdAtSKrP9y

Congratulations to our colleague Cornelia Holthausen, who will take the helm of our Macroprudential Policy and Financial Stability department from 1 December 2021.
 
We look forward to working together with Cornelia in her new role! https://t.co/IYvFxRnWbF

The #ECBForum on Banking Supervision kicks off in a week’s time.

Letter from the ECB President to Mr Gunnar Beck, MEP, on a digital euro    https://t.co/yhlO2wsN8Y

The debt-to-GDP ratio of euro area companies decreased to 80.5% at the end of June 2021, down from 81.1% a year ago. Debt in the form of securities and loans from banks and other lenders continued to grow at a lower annual rate than GDP https://t.co/hLfWkYBn0s https://t.co/EWeLuIDR5l

Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/z1z2OfOByn
Results of the September 2021 survey on credit terms and conditions in euro-denominated securities financing and over-the-counter derivatives markets (SESFOD) https://t.co/yHTCcwtfA4

Most fraudulent card transactions (80%) in 2019 resulted from online and mobile payments. Fraud committed at point-of-sale terminals and ATMs accounted for 15% and 5% of the total value of card fraud, respectively. Want to know more? Read the full report https://t.co/jdcUY0d3Oc https://t.co/EslfGvmPnu
